Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Race, Plantation Agriculture and the Environmental Politics of Pesticide Use and Regulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how the history of plantation agriculture and pesticide-intensive agricultural development shape contemporary practices of pesticide use and regulation. The project places alternate framings of pesticides - as indispensable to agricultural production or as unacceptable environmental pollutants - within the context of the racial legacy of plantation agriculture. By centering race as a factor agricultural and environmental politics, this project seeks to advance understanding of the relationship between rural inequality and environmental change. It asks how the racial politics of the plantation impacted early development of pesticides as an agricultural technology; how historic tensions between agricultural productivity and racial equity contributed to current structures of agro-environmental regulation; and how different narratives of agricultural change connected to race relations inform contemporary debates over the use and regulation of pesticides. Placing the dual objectives of racial equity and agricultural productivity at the center of inquiry, the project provides a policy-relevant analysis of the obstacles to and opportunities for greater environmental and social sustainability through agricultural practices. Oral histories produced through this study will be archived, and made publically available, in order to expand public knowledge and inform future research. The findings of the study will be shared widely through both scholarly articles and publications for broader audiences in order to deepen understanding of the relationship between environmental justice and contemporary agricultural production.

The study is positioned at the intersection of scholarship on political ecology, environmental justice, and agrarian studies. Through a case study in the Yazoo-Mississippi Delta, one of the world's most pesticide-intensive regions during the mid-20th century and a highly productive agricultural region in the present day, the research will ask how the politics of pesticide usage in agricultural production and environmental regulation reproduce, or challenge, the historical racial politics of the plantation. In order to provide a textured history of the role of pesticides in the production of racially unequal spaces, the project draws upon oral history methodologies and archival research. Through semi-structured interviews and participant observation, the study also examines how this history informs contemporary uses and understandings of pesticides in the present day. By connecting historical inquiry with contemporary research, this project will enrich understandings of the historical determinants of contemporary agro-environmental practices, while centering race as a key factor in environmental change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has provided the Co-PI with an opportunity to conduct extensive archival research, participant observation, and oral history interviews on the interlinked themes of agricultural change, race, and pesticides in the Mississippi Delta.  I conducted extensive archival research at the special collections of Mississippi State University, the University of Mississippi, and the National Archives.  I conducted 31 oral history interviews, 22 of which now comprise the “Mississippi Agriculture Oral History Collection”, publicly available through the University of Georgia Russell Library Special Collections.  This grant also enabled participant observation at a variety of agriculture-related functions.    

Through this research, I have made several significant findings.  This research has found that exposure to pesticides was widespread and largely undocumented during the period of transition from plantation agriculture to contemporary industrial agriculture in the Mississippi Delta.  Racism was a significant factor in this for several reasons.  Racism shaped who was most likely to be in the fields and exposed to pesticides. Archival sources and oral testimonies, moreover, provide significant evidence that a disregard for the health and well-being of African Americans in the Delta enabled a more general carelessness towards the health effects of pesticides.  The threat of violence and economic reprisal also prevented many African American residents of the Delta from reporting pesticide exposure.  In contrast to the oft-repeated claim that people simply didn’t know the ill effects of pesticides at the time, this research suggests that environmental racism itself contributed to systematic ignorance about the ill effects of pesticides through a disregard of the experiences and knowledge of African Americans in the Delta. 

By highlighting the multiple effects of pesticides in the context of the United States South, this research also provides an expanded understanding of the social effects of pesticides as environmental technologies.  Herbicides are rarely discussed in terms of environmental racism, but this research suggests that environmental justice is a strong analytic for understanding herbicides. In the 1960s, herbicide usage increased even as many African Americans were leaving plantations.  Gardens were an important source of food for Delta residents.  Increased herbicide drift, however, destroyed gardens and food plots at a moment when such spaces of food provisioning were especially important for African Americans, who were facing attempts by Mississippi’s white elite to use hunger as a tool of coercion.  This research, therefore, suggests that environmental justice and food justice should be a central concern in evaluating agricultural technologies.
